bibl.title: Letter from Bruce Mayne to Henry Rose Carter, January 18, 1922

div1.p: Mayne thanks Carter for his contributions to engineering abstracts and inquires about his sources.

div1.head: Letter from Bruce Mayne to Henry Rose Carter, January 18, 1922
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
N. W. C.
Wayne
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS. TENN.
Jan. 18. 1922.
My dear Doctor Carter,
div1.p:
I am back in the harness
again and going strong. I wish to thank you among
other things for your contributions to the “Engineering
Abstracts” the first copies of which I have only just
received. Griffitts who was passing through, told me
of them so I wrote immediately to be placed on the
mailing list. I am certainly pleased with your very
excellent and critical reviews.

Will you kindly be good enough to outline very
briefly the source of your material particularly
whether in the original and how exhaustively you aim
to cover the literature. As I have stated, this is
the first chance I have had to get acquainted with
the Abstracts, so am not familiar with the
scope of the field they cover.

I am particularly anxious to get saddled
to a field job, but am not certain of a problem
to select. Aside from 1. the natural conveyance
of punctipennes and 2. longevity of infection under
field conditions I have nothing in view.

Dr. Fricks is especially insistent on a strictly
practical problem, therefore am not decided on
a selection of a field problem for this season.

Will you please come to the rescue again
and suggest what you consider the best one or
two field investigations for me to embark on.

I am engaged now on blood diagnostic work, which
will probably keep one until March.
With very best regards to you and Laura. I remain
div1.closer: Ever sincerely yours. Bruce Wayne. City Hospital Laboratory. Memphis, Tenn.
